ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class was great!! I now have a new lens through which to view the climate crisis and it's a perspective that is often ignored. I also developed my writing skills
Close reading, discussion
I became so intrigued by the field of environmental humanities by taking this class, it was a great experience to immerse myself in it through the readings and discussions of this course.
I learned about climate change from a variety of sources, from films, to ancient mythical stories, to present day podcasts.
I learned about different theories about climate change and environmental crises.
I learned how to distill large questions into more specified research topics and was exposed to a field of study  environmental humanities  that I had not previously encountered.
Professor Lindskog is a fantastic writing instructor, and I saw growth in my ability to formulate and express complex thoughts.

Read a variety of works from various genres (novels, poetry, scholarly papers) and disciplines (literature, history, social sciences, environmental science). Practiced close reading of sources and writing short to medium-length papers. Themes in the course included (but were not limited to) humans' relationship with nature, the Anthropocene (is this an accurate categorization of our current age?), indigenous cultures and nature, disaster stories across human history, science communication).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course! Katja is amazing and the readings also were really though provoking. I wish that we were given more feedback throughout the course though in terms of grading, because as of the last day of classes we only just received our first grade in the course

The readings in this class were very carefully selected and provided a great introduction to the field of environmental humanities. The class discussions were very engaging, and I learned a lot from them. However, the papers were a bit challenging because we didn't get feedback on our weekly reading responses. More clear and regular feedback would benefit us greatly and would give us a clear direction for the papers.
Strengths are the reading materials and Prof Lindskog. She designs the reading and is very engaging herself so the entire course is a joy!

Strengths: Love the discussion style of the class, very engaging.

Weaknesses: Too much reading assigned per class.
I liked the group discussion structure and the range of topics in the readings.

Strengths: interesting readings 
Weaknesses: only 2 major assessments.
More readings in the mold of Ideas of Nature! That framework fundamentally changed my way of thinking about Nature as a concept, and would have loved to go even more in depth.

Strengths: The class brought together a group of students from various disciplines. The readings were generally quite interesting and enjoyable to read. Prof. Lindskog is also an excellent professor- she is approachable, understanding, and gives good feedback! 

Weaknesses: As a history major, I would have preferred a slightly more historical angle to the topics we discussed in class. However, I understand that there is a variety of students in the class and that the course is cross-listed in multiple disciplines.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES!! Take this class!! Katja is amazing and this perspective on climate change needs to be much more widely shared
Yes. Amazing intersection of EVST and humanities.

Yes! I think that this course is a wonderful representation of EVST since the readings range from climate science to fiction to environmental history. Although I'd advise them to be prepared for a lot of reading every week.
100% its definitely a class that exposed me to new material and ideas. the discussions and questions that went around were also extremely thought provoking
Yes I think everyone should develop a foundation about the nuances of environmental science and climate change
Yes.
Yes! Prof Lindskog is amazing and the content is very Interesting.

This is a can't-miss course. Former DS students already know Professor Lindskog for her compassion, wit, and dedication to student learning, but her passion for the Environmental Humanities takes this class to another level. If you have an interest in approaching critical modern environmental issues through an ethical lens, or understanding the history of the ideas that define contemporary climate discourse, take it!

Yes! This course is great for anyone who wants to discuss climate change and society in depth. If you prefer an interdisciplinary approach, all the better- this course touches upon and synthesizes several disciplines.
